en: [Letter] 1804 Aug. 9, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Colo[nel] Joseph McMin [i.e. McMinn], Colo[nel] Samuel Wear, and Maj[or] John Cowan / John Sevier

This document is a letter written by John Sevier, Governor of Tennessee from 1796-1801 and 1803-1809, to Colonel Joseph McMinn, Colonel Samuel Wear, and Major John Cowan, dated August 9, 1804. In the letter, Sevier informed these men that he had received word of a meeting to be held with the commissioners of Georgia regarding a road that would be built connecting the two states, which would also run through Cherokee lands. Sevier commanded the men to attend the meeting, and he gave further instructions of the agreements to be made with the Georgian commissioners. Sevier wanted to make certain that both states would have an equal amount of work to do in constructing the road and reap an equal number of advantages from its existence.

body.value: Knoxville 9th August 1804 Gentlemen Having received notice from the Georgian Commissioners proposing a meeting at James Vans on the 15th Instant, you will readily discover the necessity of repairing to that place with the utmost dispatch Permit me to recommend in the first place an agreement to be made with the Georgian Commissioners Consigning to each State an equal part of the road most conveinant convenient for each party to open and clear out If this point should be settled and agreed upon, very probably your place of meeting will be considered near the Middle Ground Secondly you will proceed to explore and Mark out the nearest, best, and most conveinant convenient routs routes , for waggon wagon roads, leading from the two stations agreed upon between the United States and Cherokees, ( towit to wit ) "From Southwest point and Tellico Blockhouse ," to such part of the way and place as may be agreed upon by the Commissioners: The

none: [Letter] 1804 Aug. 9, Knoxville, [Tennessee, to] Colo[nel] Joseph McMin [i.e. McMinn], Colo[nel] Samuel Wear, and Maj[or] John Cowan / John Sevier : page 2

body.value: The two roads leading from the aforesaid points, to intersect each other conformably to the articles of agreement between the united United States and the Indians. You will also agree and conclude upon a certain and Suitable place to prefix a twin pike to be erected. As the two roads to be laid off from Tellico and Southwest point will require some time, I therefore recommend the road leading from Tellico , to be the first marked out, provided you can not cannot have them both laid off at or near the same time I have observed that probably your place of meeting would be about the Middle Ground, but you will please to Notice, that for a great part of the Way leading from Tennessee river River there is are two roads to be cut on our side, which considerably Stretch and lengthen the distance, and it aught ought to be so arranged that Tennessee should not have more miles to cut, than Georgia , who have has resolved to pay an equal Moiety of the expense. Those indifinate indefinite points it is expected will be agreed upon and adjusted,
